column2: 'Super Thursday' voting in the UK: A new low for Labour? (plus #DogsAtPollingStations) (Update)
column5: Voting is taking place in Wales in Scotland and all over England today. There are so many elections taking place that the British press has dubbed it â€œSuper Thursday.â€ Yesterday Boris Johnson put out this brief video encouraging everyone to get out and vote. As I write this polls will be closing fairly soon; however because of COVID restrictions the results of nearly all of those elections arenâ€™t expected until Friday morning at the soonest and some wonâ€™t be resolved before Sunday. The Guardian put together a list of when certain race results will be available here. What nearly everyone agrees going into Super Thursday is that itâ€™s likely to be a pretty good day for Boris Johnson and the conservatives and likely to be a very bad day for Keir Starmerâ€™s Labour Party. Jubilant Tories predicted that Labour will â€˜hit bottomâ€™ under Keir Starmer tonight amid signs Super Thursday will see them inflict more huge blows on the Red Wallâ€¦ Bullish Conservative MPs who have been on the ground in the constituency today pointed to a â€˜clear swingâ€™ towards them. â€˜If you thought the bottom of Labour was Corbyn then you are wrongâ€™ one told MailOnline. Meanwhile Labour activists doorknocking sounded relentlessly glum. â€˜We are suffering from Long Corbynâ€™ one senior figure said in a grim coronavirus analogy. â€œLong Corbynâ€ is a brilliant description. You probably recall that previous Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn who campaigned as a Democratic Socialist led his party to an epic defeat in 2019. At the time there were a number of voices who pointed out that Corbyn had something in common with Bernie Sanders and that his loss under a cloud of anti-Semitism allegations connected to the Labour Party might portend bad things for Sanders here in the US. But the other problem for Labour this year is that people are pretty happy with Boris Johnsonâ€™s handling of the vaccination program the result of which is that the 7-day average of deaths as of yesterday was 13 for the entire UK. Boris had been in a lot of trouble early on last year when he seemed to be heading down a herd immunity path similar to what Sweden ended up doing. But he reversed that and by most accounts did a good job with the vaccinations. In fact he can credibly argue that his success in pushing through Brexit was part of the reason the UK did so well scooping up vaccines while efforts lagged in the EU. Even some Brexit critics have admitted it seems to have helped in this instance. One of the races being watched as a bellwether this year is the election in Hartlepool. Hartlepool is a town in northern England which has elected a Labour MP in every election since 1964. But this year Labourâ€™s own internal polling shows they are in bad shape and likely to lose the seat to the conservatives: Hartlepool is the backdrop for the first byelection since Boris Johnsonâ€™s landslide victory in December 2019. It is seen as a key test of Labourâ€™s appeal to its traditional heartlands just over a year after Starmer became leader with a pledge to rebuild the â€œred wallâ€. The mood among some Labour figures in Hartlepool was â€œpretty desperateâ€ sources said. Internal data from six weeks of campaigning shows that just over 40% of previous party supporters have said they will vote for the party again this week. The figure is what is known as a â€œpromise rateâ€ â€“ who people say they will vote for â€“ and is based on the canvassing of more than 10000 people in the town most of whom have recently voted Labour. â€œIf we were knocking on every single door and getting 40% we could win it depending on how it splits. But weâ€™re only getting about 40% of people who we think are Labour so itâ€™s not greatâ€ said one insider. The results in Hartlepool should come in very early Friday morning which will be prime time here on the west coast. If I see any updates tonight Iâ€™ll add them below. Finally since thereâ€™s not much happening today as far as results some in the UK seem to be having fun taking their dogs to the polls. The hashtag #DogsAtPollingStations was trending on Twitter.
